central_thesis: The Tarot is a symbolic language that reveals the fundamental principles of the universe and the path of human spiritual evolution, particularly through the lens of the Judgement (Key 20), which represents the awakening of higher consciousness and the union of the personal will with the Divine Will.

structure_content.summary: This section delves into the symbolism of Tarot Key 20, Judgement. It identifies Gabriel as the angel, linking him to the moon and the number 2. The key's central theme is the resurrection of the personality from three-dimensional consciousness through divine power, rather than personal effort. The geometrical design of the angel symbolizes the fourth dimension. The twelve rays represent the Divine Name 'Hoa' and the True Self. The seven rays descending from the trumpet signify the awakening of higher consciousness through sound vibrations linked to interior centers. The icebergs symbolize the need to 'fix the volatile' (conscious energy) to achieve emancipation. The sea represents race-consciousness and the termination aspect of judgement. The three coffins and figures symbolize the man (self-conscious awareness), woman (subconsciousness), and child (regenerated personality), corresponding to Osiris, Isis, and Horus, and also forming the letters L.V.X. (light).

Pages 4-6 introduce the 'Cube of Space' as a symbolic map for understanding consciousness and the Tarot Keys. Each coordinate line of the cube represents an aspect of consciousness (life, substance, activity) and is linked to specific Hebrew letters and Tarot Keys. The first coordinate (Aleph) represents superconsciousness and life; the second (Mem) represents substance and water; the third (Shin) represents activity and fire. The diagonals within the cube symbolize paths of ascent to the center (consciousness) and correspond to Hebrew final letters. The journey to the center involves overcoming the 'Dweller on the Threshold' and progressing through specific keys representing psychological states.

This section (Pages 7-9) emphasizes the importance of Key 20 in the current age, which allows for conscious, intentional spiritual evolution. It describes the union of the divine spark in man with the Divine Being as a result of attuning personal will to Divine Will. This is not an achievement but an awareness of an inherent connection. 'Personal will' is seen as a focus of the Cosmic Will. Will-power is equated with light-power and fire (Shin). The text contrasts 'personal will' with the 'true Primal Will', stating that living according to the latter constitutes a true 'judgement'. This leads to a different conception of time and space, akin to that described in 2 Peter 3:8. True attunement with the Divine (Jehovah) grants powers. The text warns against seeking powers for selfish reasons, as these 'wild beasts' can be dangerous. True occult training aims at evolving beyond Homo sapiens, leading to a state of pure spirit and liberation from materialistic delusions and space-time concepts. This awakening is the 'end of the old man' and precedes the final stage of unfoldment discussed in Key 21.

key_concepts.definition: Represents the awakening of higher consciousness and the resurrection of the personality from limited, three-dimensional awareness through divine power. It signifies the union of personal will with the Universal Divine Will.
The angel of Key 20, symbolizing the 'Might of God'. He is associated with the moon and acts as a messenger, calling consciousness from a 'deathlike sleep' of material belief.
Symbolized by the geometrical design of the angel in Key 20. It represents a higher mode of consciousness beyond the three perceived dimensions of space.
The presiding power in Judgement, representing the root-power of reflection and consciousness from which all ideas arise.

An alchemical concept applied to consciousness. The 'volatile' is conscious energy (water); 'fixing' it means arresting its flow, often through abstraction and mathematics, leading to emancipation from illusion.

A symbolic geometrical model used to map different aspects of consciousness, represented by coordinate lines and diagonals, each linked to Hebrew letters and Tarot Keys. It illustrates the paths of consciousness's movement and interaction.
A state of awareness represented by the first coordinate of the Cube of Space (Aleph), associated with life and interior consciousness.

The text distinguishes between the limited, ego-driven 'personal will' and the universal 'Divine Will'. True spiritual progress involves aligning personal will with the Divine Will, leading to the recognition of the Life-power's action within.
Refers to ordinary human consciousness, limited by space-time concepts. The ultimate goal of evolution described is to transcend this state.
The only constant, unchanging Reality, considered the sure foundation for life, concealed by myriad forms but ever-present.

practical_system.description: The text presents a philosophical and symbolic system for spiritual development rather than a direct set of ritualistic instructions. The 'practical' aspect lies in the contemplation and application of the symbolic meanings of the Tarot keys, especially Judgement (Key 20), and the understanding of consciousness through the Cube of Space model. The system encourages practitioners to align their personal will with the Divine Will, recognize the limitations of materialist perception, and consciously evolve beyond ordinary human consciousness ('Homo sapiens') towards 'Pure Spirit'. The Cube of Space serves as a mental map for navigating internal states, with specific paths and coordinates representing psychological processes and stages of awakening.
tools: Tarot Deck (specifically focusing on Key 20, Judgement, but implicitly all keys).
The concept and diagrams of the Cube of Space.
Qabalistic principles (e.g., Divine Names, Hebrew letters).
Hermetic and Alchemical symbolism (e.g., 'fix the volatile').
A personal 'occult diary' (mentioned as a tool for practice).
rituals: Contemplation of Tarot Key 20 (Judgement) and its symbolism.
Meditation on the principles of aligning personal will with Divine Will.
Study and visualization of the Cube of Space to map internal consciousness and identify paths of spiritual ascent.
Reflection on the 'fix the volatile' concept in relation to managing conscious energy.
Self-examination to shed materialistic delusions and overcome the 'old man' archetype.

relevant_quotes.text: The idea here is that the presiding power in the scene is the power of reflection, the root-power of the Universal Memory. Gabriel means "Might of God", and the suggestion is, therefore, that human personality is raised from the "death" of three-dimensional consciousness by a power descending from above, rather than by its own efforts.

Clouds surround the angel because the true nature of the Self is veiled by appearances, and the substance of these appearances is really the same as the stream of consciousness typified by the robe of the High Priestess.
The sea, moreover, is the end of a flowing of water. Thus it suggests the same notions of termination and conclusion which we found associated with the word "judgement".

The coffins are rectangular to suggest the apparent solidity and impenetrability of three-dimensional forms. The human figures stand upright so that their bodies are at right angles to the bottoms of the coffins. This intimates something which is impossible to delineate--the mathematical definition of the Fourth Dimension as that which is at right angles to all three dimensions of space as we perceive them.

The three figures represent self-conscious awareness (the man), subconsciousness (the woman), and their product, the regenerated personality (the child). They correspond also to the Egyptian triad, Osiris the father, Isis the mother, and Horus the child.

The man is in an attitude of passive adoration. In four-dimensional consciousness, or the Perpetual Intelligence, the self-conscious mind realizes that it does nothing whatever of itself. It is merely a channel through which the higher life descends to lower levels of manifestation.

The flesh of the figures is gray to show that they have overcome all the pairs of opposites. Gray is the tint resulting from the blending of any two complementary colors, such as white and black, red and green, and so on.

Thus Key 20 suggests the union of the spark of divinity inherent in man with the totality of the Divine Being. This is a direct consequence of conscious attunement of the personal will to the intellectually recognized Divine Will.
Will-power is light-power and light-power is the highest meaning of the ancient symbol of FIRE, correlated by Qabalists with the letter Shin.

When, as a rational process, a human being deliberately chooses to put aside the illusive "personal will", and to live in thought, word and deed as "an unprofitable servant" of the true Primal Will, he really begins to live. This is truly a judgement, and the student who arrives at this realization comes to judgement on the last day of the old heaven and the old earth.

There is only one constant, unchanging Reality, and that is Pure Spirit. It was in the beginning, is now--concealed by myriad forms, both visible and as yet unknown to us--and ever shall be the only Sure Foundation on which we may with utter confidence rest our lives from day to day.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant to students of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in the Qabalistic and Hermetic interpretations of Tarot. It offers a sophisticated symbolic framework for understanding consciousness, spiritual evolution, and the process of awakening. The integration of the Cube of Space provides a unique geometrical and psychological map for occult practice, offering a structured approach to internal transformation.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Advanced students of Tarot, Qabalah, Hermeticism, and esoteric philosophy. Practitioners interested in structured, symbolic systems for self-transformation and the development of higher consciousness. Individuals familiar with Manly P. Hall's previous works and esoteric concepts.
